Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n><n>### Response:		<n>

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The only baggage the woman checked was a drawstring bag, where was she heading with it? Choices:  A: garbage can B: military C: jewelry store D: safe E: airport<n><n>### Response:		E<n>### Instruction<n><n>### Demostration:A: garbage can<n>C: jewelry studio<n>D: safe<n>E: airport<n><n>The woman bought a drawstring bag to put her luggage in.<n><n>### Response<n><n>A: garbage can<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: Cindy likes to drink coffee with her friends. She likes a 20-ounce cup, but she can't drink coffee without adding sugar to it. She likes two teaspoons for every cup she drinks, but she often drinks four cups and uses four teaspoons of sugar for each. How much sugar can she use if she fills up a 20-cup sugar container?<n>Answer: 20 teaspoons<n><n>The woman can fill up 20 cups of sugar using her 20-ounce bag at two teaspoons per cup. This will use 1/2 teaspoon of sugar per ounce used, so 20 ounces of sugar used will be equivalent to 40 teaspoons. She likes to drink 4 cups of coffee with 4 teaspoons of coffee in each, making a total of 16 ounces of coffee (4 X 4 cups) per cup. If she is filling her 20-cup container with sugar by only putting in the equivalent amount of sugar to that of her 20-ounces containers of coffee, then she will use 40 teas of sugar.<n><n>### The solution uses the same logic except that she uses the formula C +S = 10 which results in a different solution.<n>### Write the formula you used to solve the problem.<n><n>`x*2` equals 20 ounCES of sugar.<n><n>How much sugar is inside a 20-CUp Sugar CUp<n>### Instruction <n><n>Answer the question(s).<n>### Input<n>Input:<n>How much do you pay to get your hair done every 5 months?<n>Answer: $285<n><n><n>### Response <n><n>Hair was cut every 5 months<n>4 haircuts: $111/hair cut<n>1<n><n>### Demorization<n><n>` x = 5`<n><n>hair

Write a response that appropriatley completes the request.  <n><n>##### Demonstration Input: One night a teenager sleeps in and then tries to get a few hours of sleep in the morning without having to go to school, resulting in getting only 3.5 total hours of sleep. How many hours of sleep would have been better if this teenager got 3 hours of "extra" sleep?<n>### Demonstrait Answer:<n>4 total hours of sleep would have bettered off if this teenager had slept 3 hours.  The total time of sleeping he actually did is 3.5.  He slept 5 hours before sleeping again, sleeping 2.5 hours.  We subtract the 2.5 hours from the 5 hours, and we get the correct answer of 2.5 added to 1.

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. Use first person pronouns (I think, I like).<n><n>Evil has to be used very sparingly. I'm not even sure "little" is right, I mean, it's a completely different story from scary. The only word you could really use from "halloween" is "halloween". Horrible is just the same thing as scary, and small is the same thing as little. Just a little scary would be a good compromise.<n>

The user is supposed to answer the question. After entering the user's answer, if the answer is incorrect, ask the user again. Repeat this process until the user gives no answer.<n><n>### If Statement<n>If the user does not give any response, the program should exit with the "exit" statement.<n>### If statement<n>The following if statement can be used to ask for a password. If the user does not give the password the program can exit with an exit command to end the program.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>## Question 7<n>How do I create a switch statement that accepts multiple values.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>## Instruction: How does this work:<n>It creates a variable and stores the answer. In turn, it does not need to repeatedly ask the user for answers. The if-else statement executes only once, even if it gets multiple answers.<n><n>## Instruction - Test:<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Follow the instructions below to implement the solution.<n><n>### Comments:<n>Ask the user his/her height in feet.<n><n>### Question:<n>What should the first line of the program be?<n><n>### Response<n>Answer to:<n><n>if Statement<n><n>If the user is 3 feet tall, print a message.<n><n>### if else statement:<n>If the answer is 6, print a message. <n><n>### If statement:<n>If the user is between 6 and 10 feet tall, print a different message.<n><n>## Instruces:<n><n>## Comments:<n><n><n>## Question:<n><n><n>## Response:<n>Answer to:<n>if Statement<n>The second question is incorrect.<n><n>## Instuces:<n>Write a program that allows the user to choose the answer that corresponds to his height.<n><n>## Instrace<n>After the user enters the height in feet, print something like “You are <length> feet tall.”<n><n><n><n>## Instruce:<n>If it turns out that I gave the wrong answer, ask the user if he is < 3>, < 5>, < 6>, < 7>, < 8>, <

Really, she didn't know what that thing had an inkwell in the first place.  What piece of furniture might have been on her run? Choices:  A: front of door B: bedroom C: desk D: table E: living room<n><n>### Response:		What is the number of hours Sarah will spend cleaning up the mess?<n><n>### Output: A: 4 hours B: 11 hours C: 4 hours D: 13 hours E: 2 hours<n><n>### Output Explanation: A: She has to wipe up the ink.  When each wipe takes at least an hour, and she's cleaned the mess twice. B: She has to take out her old rug and take her new rug to the store.  It will take an hour to unpack the new rug and wipe up the old rug. After that, she will need to pack up her new rug and will be spending 2 hours transporting it and bringing it into the house again. C: She will take both her old and new rug outside and pack it into her new car. While this takes longer, it is more efficient.  With a car, she can go as fast to the store as she wants and can take her rug right in the room.  But if she has to take it outside to clean, we are now using up 4 hours of transportation. D: She can go inside the store to get her new rug.  It takes 30 minutes at the most for the delivery to the new house. So after wiping the old rug, unpacking the new rug, and putting the old rug away, she still has 2 more hours left. E: We can reuse the old rug. The old rug's packaging will be left behind to clean up. So she only has to spend 2 hours cleaning up the mess.<n>

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where are people likely to stand at an intersection? Choices:  A: cars B: city street C: street corner D: fork in road E: at a red light<n><n>### Response:		C<n>### Demonstation:<n><n>### 💡<n><n>### Input-Output:<n><n>```bash<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n>import numpy as np<n>from typing import List<n><n>def getNums(input:str,output:str=None):<n>    numList:List[float] = [float(x) for x in input.split()]<n>    resultNum = sum([x + y for x, y in zip(numList,numList[1:])])<n>    if output:<n>        print(resultNum,')')<n>    else:<n>        return resultNum<n><n>def main():<n>    nums = input = getNums(input)<n><n>    mynums = [i * i for i in nums] # Calculate all unique squares numbers<n>    uniqueSquares=len(myNum) # number of unique numbers<n>    uniqueSum = np.add.reduce(mynums)<n>    ans = [1] * (uniqueSum)<n>    for i in ans:<n>        print(ans[i],i)<n>          <n>if __name__ == "__main__":<n>    main()<n>```<n><n>## Output:<n>```bash<n>#Input<n>1.4 2.45 10.33 9.74 11.67 65.22<n><n>#Output<n>1<n>4<n>2<n>45<n>10<n>33<n>97<n>45<n>```<n><n>## Task:Input-Output:<n><n>**Increasing:** For each number in the sequence, double the previous number in the sequence.<n><n>**Increase-Doubling the number before:** Find the smallest number in a sequence and multiply it by 3, and then double the number after that.<n><n>**Increment-Doubling the next number:** Find the smallest two numbers in a sequence and multiply each one by 2. Then, add those two numbers together and double them.<n><n>**Minimum-Sum:** For each number, double the previous two numbers. Once a sequence of three or more numbers is found, find the smallest number in the sequence and multiply it by the sum of the other numbers in the sequence.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Reasoning:John feels that if there were a closer job available, he would happily move closer to his family.<n><n>### Input/Data/Parameters:<n><n>### Output:<n><n><li > <h3 id="7:C2F623AA-8286-4754-8242-14371BB80614" data-fullback="2:C2F63170-C850-4DBD-8463-457AA9C08A6E" class="data-output"> 12 hours<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>### Code:<n><n>```python<n>if(input='What is the 12 hour equivalent of 3204 hours')<n>  answer='12 hours'<n><n>elif(input='Who got 40 years in jail')<n>  answer='Jack'<n><n>elif( input = 'What number, the product of which by 1/3 is 4/5')<n>  answer = 5<n><n>elif(input = 'Which is the biggest country in the world?')<n>  answer = USA<n><n>elif(input == 'What is 75 percent of 20')<n>  answer = (20*.75)<n><n>elif(input= 'What is the length and width of an 11 foot X 21 foot rectangulum')<n>  #length=(11-1) * 1440<n>  #width=(21-1) *1440<n>  <n>var<n>  width =1220<n>  length = 1148<n>  <n>length = width - 1<n>answer = length<n><n>elif(input== 'What is the radius of a circular area that has a 400 cm diameter?')<n><n>  radius = 200/2<n><n>else<n><n>echo "Invalid request: " + input.toUpperCase()

They don't want to use buses as they could lose some of their equipment. They are planning to transport all of their instruments on trucks and to drive a van carrying the rest of their equipment. If the van can cover 541 miles and it has 8 passengers, how many trips will the van make?<n><n>### Response2:<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input3: There is an amusement park that takes up 283 acres of land. A large bouncy castle occupies 10 acres and the roller coaster occupies 73.3 acres. How many acres of land do the trucks take up?<n><n><n>### Solution:<n>**NOTE: I'm using python here**<n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/python<n><n>import sys<n>import os<n><n><n>def main():<n>    file_name = sys.argv[1]<n>    file_name_path = os.path.basename(file_name)<n>    iffile(instr1,instr2,instr3)<n>    print(file_name_path)<n><n>input = input(14)<n><n><n>ifile = []<n>i = 0<n><n>def ifile(a=input[0:len(input)],b=input[len(input) - 2:len(input) - len(input)],c=input[len(<n>    input) - len(input)]):<n>    for x in a.split():<n>        if x == b.split():<n>            i = i + 1<n>        elif x == c.split():<n>            input[<n>                len(input) - len([x for x in input if x == a.split()])] = i<n><n>ifile()<n>```<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: cause death B: cause bleeding C: falling down D: become infected E: claim insurance<n><n>### Response:		<n>The worst outcome of an injury is the injury itself. If it causes death or bleeding, then the person is also injured. Other outcomes, like claiming insurance or falling down, are only effects of a bad outcome.<n><n>### Inputs: How has technology affected the way we work and what do you predict for the future? Choices: <n><n> A: we no longer need to work in a particular location B: we work more hours than before we can work anytime we want C: we will no longer work D: we will no longer need to have money to survive E: humanity will no longer be needed<n><n>### Response<n>There are two aspects to how technology has affected the way we work. The first is that people who might have had to commute to an office or other location can now work from home on their laptops. This cuts down on the number of hours worked, as we can now work flexible hours and work in many locations (like on a train, in a coffee shop, etc). The second is that people have started to have side jobs (on Fiverr or other sites for example) to supplement their day job and bring in more money. <n><n>The future will not be as dystopian as most sci-fi portrays. We will still have to work, in one form or another as we are built for work. What the work will look like is something we can't expect, but I don't think humanity is doomed. But, maybe it is...<n><n>### Instructions : Find the next highest number out of 71,868,713,592.<n><n>### The next highest number out of: Choices: <n>A: 1 B: 2 C: 3 D: 4 E: 5 F: 6 G: 7 H: 8 I: 9 J: 10<n><n>### The Correct Answer<n>A: <n><n>### Instructor: Fill in the blank with the correct answer. <n> 1. If you do not have an answer in mind, it is good to try to read the question and determine which items would most likely be contained in which container.  <n>

As an example, the function is used on a list of integers from -8 to +8.<n>The second question can be given with a range of numbers, for instance<n>"

Choices:  A: living B: feeling good C: hyperventilate D: look around E: breathe deeply<n><n>### Response:		 Look around<n><n>### Explanation:<n>This problem asks us to come up with a statement that describes a task. To determine which answer will work, we have to first understand the statements available. The statements are:<n><n>-  A: living<n>-  B: feeling good<n>-  C: hyperventilating<n>-  D: looking around<n>-  E: breathing deeply<n><n>First two statements make up a short phrase. These two are not independent nor are they the only ways to accomplish the task but they will work. Next statement is an independent task statement and not in the form the question ask, I don't think it will work because I doubt the response can ever make up this phrases "looked around" in the question statement. Also, the last statement alone is also not in the form and cannot be used as its response so this can also be ruled out.<n><n>So only two statements that can work and that I think you want to use as your response<n><n>-  A and B<n>-  C and D<n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following sentence completion question.<n><n>##|The response: (Answer: E)<n><n>##|The explanation:  It's always amazed me how many students don't do their homework, and just because they're lazy doesn't mean they should be punished. I believe homework is one of<n>the most valuable ways a teacher can teach a subject,<n><n>##|I think you got the response right and what you said is pretty much the same<n><n>### Inputs:  The two best teams in the state are going to face off next week in the championship game.<n><n>### Input 2: He went to the library to get some books for his homework.<n><n>### Reponse:  The librarian suggested the 9 year old student check out the encyclopedia because I'm sure he was reading too much and needed a break from studying.  But I was right-- that's <n>the book I'm looking for!<n><n>### Explantion:<n><n>I think you should use the statement in number two as response.<n><n>The first one uses presenting statements and so it cannot be as a response to the instruction in number two.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Having a car in the city seemed to be more trouble than it was worth, the man still had to walk to and from the what after commuting? Choices:  A: hear testimony B: go somewhere C: see exhibits D: outdoor concert E: surf net<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A and B: A - you can go to a museum, listen to a testimony<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately answers a request. Be sure to include relevant detail.<n><n>### Input text:<n><n>There will be 5 banners on display in a town square for the next event that will last 3 months. What would the cost to erect a 9-foot banner be for 3 months if the cost is $25 per month and one square foot cost $0.25?<n><n>Erecting banners is a project in town. One banner is going to be displayed for 3 months. So, there are 2700 square feet. If each banner is 9 foot, then we can say that each banner will take 2700 sq.ft divided by 9 feet = about 30 banners. So, each banner will take about 30 or so sq.ft/month. As given in the question, each banner costs $25/month. So, we can calculate the cost to display all the banners for 3 months like this:<n><n>Cost to display all banners for 1 banner for 1 months = $25<n><n>Cost to display banners for all banners for duration 3 months = $25 * 3 = $75<n><n>So, the cost to display ALL banners for a duration of 3 months is $75.<n><n>### Summary:<n><n>This program does exactly what the request states. It gives the cost to erect 5 banners for 9-foot banners, so it displays them for 3 months.<n><n>### Comments:<n><n>You should consider using a `do...while()` loop for this program. However, not all students have experience using while loops. Therefore, feel free to use a `while()` loop instead.<n>

In<n>particular, they should avoid<n>excessive indentation of paragraphs.<n>There is no maximum length for the<n>commands or responses,<n>though in particular the responses<n>should be concise enough to be read<n>in 4 characters per second.<n><n>The input consists of a list of commands<n>and responses.  Each command is followed<n>by a space character.  No two commands<n>have the<n>same first character, and<n>a particular command can<n>only appear once per line.<n>All other characters<n>can occur any number<n>of times on a single line.  <n><n>A program is a sequence of instructions.  <n>Each instruction has the following form:<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiplechoice question.<n><n>## Instrucciones:<n><n>La usuario proporciona el input en la forma de series comandos en un solo cadena. <n>Givente la secuencia de comandos, el programa responde con una correspondencia apropiada la siguiente línea, con una correspondencia por cada comando.<n><n>Las correspondencias deberá ser cortas para que sean fichas de lo suficientemente corto como para encajar <n>entirament en 4 palabras por segundo.  En particular, deben evitarse <n>el exceso de caracteres de parrafo. <n>Quien ha no máximo longitud para los comandos de las correspondencias,<n>pero en particular las correspondencias debe ser concisa lo bastante para leer <n>en 4 carácteres por segundo.

Choices:  A: aquarium B: mediterranean sea C: south pacific D: pool hall E: pacific ocean<n><n>### Response:		Aquarium<n><n>### Input<n>Input: If I were you, I wouldn't play those two card games.<n>Input: The number that does the same math operation as the sum of the two numbers is called the difference between them.<n>Input: The average is the sum of two numbers divided by two.<n>Input: The product of two numbers is the number that produces the two original numbers when you multiply them together.<n>Input: The quotient of two numbers is their product divided by their sum.<n>Input: As a ratio, the product of two numbers is called the reciprocal of the quotient of the two numbers.<n>Input: The sum of a sum is the sum of two other sums.<n>Input: The difference of the reciprocal of a difference is a sum.<n>Input: The reciprocal of sum is the sum of the sum of the sum.<n>Input: In a sum, a product becomes a reciprocal of a sum.<n>Input. The difference between sum of sum and difference is a quotient.<n>Input: If sum is reciprocal, sum of sum is reciprocal of difference.<n>Input: If difference is reciprocal, difference of sum of sum is a product.<n>Input: If quotient is reciprocal, quotient of a sum is reciprocal.<n>Input: If a product is reciprocal, a difference is reciprocal sum.<n>Input: If the product is reciprocal of the sum, the difference is reciprocal of a product.<n>Input. The sum of the sum is reciprocal sum of the sum. The sum of difference is sum. The product of sum is reciproval sum of the sum. A sum of sum is reciprocale division of divisor. A difference of difference is divisor. A difference is reciprocal to dividend of a sum. The sum of reciprocal sum is resultant of a quotient. Sum of sum in reciprocal is reciprocal sum sum. The reciprocal of reciprocal sum sum is the result of a product. The reciprocal product is a sum of a difference. A reciprocal sum is reciprocal difference. The reciprocal difference is sum of the reciprocal product. The dividend of a quotient is reciproval sum. Division of reciprocal sum of difference is the dividend. The reciprocal to divisor of a product

How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. Choices:  A: football stadium B: apartment C: surface of earth D: car show E: house<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n><br><n><n>### Review:<n>When a choice has two answers (for example, in the above question), the choice that has both answers is incorrect.<n>The choices with one answer, other than the choice with both answers, are the correct choices.<n>In this review, "A" is the correct choice (the choice with both answers).<n><n>### Commentary:<n>This is a very difficult task to write. Above all, a writer of the instructions needs to be very careful that the choice that has both correct answers is very obvious.  The writer needs to be sure, as much as possible, that there is no choice with both correct answers for the student to find.<n><n><n><n><n>

Note that the Input is "What is your pet's<n> name?". They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If you're traveling along a highway what item made of paper can you use to find your way? Choices:  A: united states B: atlas C: developed land D: park E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		<n>E: countryside or developed land<n><n>[Read instructions & examples](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JV37b2s_7J0R4vxXLxqx3xjvDVXsDVYn6DhNvMZ4i2M/edit?usp=sharing)<n>

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>* The choice of "A: lungs and diaphrams" suggests that the human body takes in something other than oxygen while breathing, namely the lungs and the diaphrams.  It omits the crucial choice of "B: oxygen" which the correct choice indicates it must in order to be accepted for life.  It is not necessarily the response given in every situation or every circumstance, but since this is a multiple choice question it is the only acceptable answer that would satisfy anyone giving the task.<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>function breath_taking() {<n>  var a = ["E:"open_throat"]<n>  var b = ["B:"oxygen"]<n>  var c = ["C:"abdominal_muscles"]<n>  var d = ["A:"lungs_and_diaphrams"]<n><n>  console.log(a)<n>  console.log("--------------")<n>  console.log("/*********** ")<n>  console.log(".*\\*\\* ")<n><n>  if (answer.question == "What do humans take in breathing?") {<n>    console.log(b)<n>  } else {<n>    console.error("Error: Input does not match question being requested")<n>  }<n>  <n>  console.log()<n>  if (answer && answer.question == a) {<n>    console.info("Input matches question")<n>  } <n>  else {<n>    console("Input does not match question")<n>  }<n>  return "E:"open_throt<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```sh<n>(node.)<n>/*********<n>.*\\*\\*<n>E:open_throt<n>------------<n>```<n>

B.<n><n>### Hint:When you're a broken person, the only place you can ever "get down" is a broken place like a hospital bed. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Dry and cracked heels are found on? Choices:  A: boot B: the desert C: loaf of bread D: foot E: hock<n><n>### Response:		(A) Boots.<n><n>### Why: The feet are in direct contact with the ground when using boots. As a result, the feet are subjected to constant pressure and the moisture inside the boots prevents the formation of the needed oils to support and lubricate the foot and heel.<n><n>### Question: What is the capital of Canada?<n><n>### Response:"A: Ottawa."<n><n>### Why:"A" is the capital of Canada because it is the country's seat of government.<n><n>### Subject: What are the main reasons why e-commerce failed in the mid-1990's?<n><n>### Sub-subject: Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>### Response:(A) A,B,C&amp;D<n><n>### Why:(A)"Business to business (B2B) marketplaces, the core of an online business, failed without adequate customer adoption.""The dotcom bubble went pop."<n><n>### Question:"What is a 'viral' email?"<n><n>### Response:`B: An email that grows rapidly because of the forwarding it receives from others.`<n><n>### Why:`B`: A "virus" is defined as a program whose spread depends on inserting itself in other programs or on a computer, without the user being aware of it. Viruses can spread over networks and from one computer of a system to another, damaging data and rendering computer systems useless."<n><n>

Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		The answer is B<n><n>### Input-Response-Output Format<n><n>### Description of the task:<n>Write a function called answer() that takes three parameters (answer, choice, and response): answer is a string describing the answer to the question or problem, choice is a string description of one of the choices for the multiple choice question, and response is the answer selected by the user if the input does not match the answer.<n><n>### Examples of correct responses:<n><n>### Demilneration of the example instructions:<n>1. The first instruction contains one statement.  Input contains the answer, choice, and response for the response to the example question.  Output contains a string describing the selected response to the multiple choice question.<n>```<n>A<n>B<n>B<n>C<n>C<n>D<n>E<n>A<n>E<n>E<n>```<n>Based on the above multiple choice answers, the selected response is answered in the corresponding order in the list.  For this example the output is the text: answer(“A”, “C”, “B”).<n><n>1. The second instruction contains two statements.  This is an example of data input into another function.  Input contains the text describing the data.  Output contains the same description of the data as input.  Here the data is the text of the name of the function.<n>```<n>The name of the function<n>The string describing the data<n>```<n>We can see that the input matches the output and that we can use the text as if it already exists in the environment.<n><n>### Example usage:<n>input = {question: "How many miles has she walked", choiceA: "C", choiceB: "D", choiceC: "E", choiceD: "A"}<n>getAnswers(input, answer, "John walks 30 miles a week.")<n>function answer(question, choice, response) {<n>  if (response === choice) return answer(question, choice);<n>  return choice;<n>}<n>This returns the same string based on the chosen response<n><n>### Input Formats<n>Your code must take the following data form:<n>* The function to be called should expect the problem or question as input, so it must be passed in as the first argument as a string.<n>* You can only use the parameters answer(“question”), choice(“A”, “B”, "C”, "D" or "E

Choices:  A: front door B: newspaper C: post office D: package E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Instructions:Howdy, Pilgrim! A word is represented by the characters  in it's dictionary. You are given a word, and need to work out its dictionary using an alphabet. However, the task is not as simple. <n>We will use your alphabet to spell out letters.  In the word, you can only pick one of your letters at a time for each position.  Therefore, you can't choose a letter that isn't in your alphabet.  For example, if you have a letter 'a' & 'b', then you cannot choose the letter 'A' at the position 'A' <n>You also can't choose two letters at a time. In other words, the letter 'A' cannot be both in the position 'A' and in the position 'B'.<n>### Input:'Dog' A:  Dog<n><n>### Response:'Dog' B: A O G<n><n>### Output:A B G<n><n>######Input:'Fog' A:  F O G<n><n>######Response:'Fog' B: A B<n><n>### Output:'Fog' B:'A B<n><n>### Instructor:You are stuck in the wreckage of your vehicle, and it is unlikely you will live long enough without sustenance. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What is a negative effect to someone other than a spouse when two spouses are getting divorced? Choices:  A: lot of grief B: depression C: no spouse D: lose money E: children suffer<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E: (or D)<n><n>Losing one's spouse is the greatest loss that can occur in his life. It happens when either he or she decide to leave one's partner and start living alone or with new partner. It is said that leaving the marriage might lead two people to depression. Divorce is always not a pleasant thing to the children who are affected most when the couple decided to separate or divorce.<n><n>### Input :What is a negative effect an employee of a business receives when the business loses a customer? Choices:A: no promotionB: depressionC: no good salaryD: loss of employmentE: job loss<n><n>### Response :<n><n>E: (E)<n><n>This is because when an employee is hired they are paid according to the work they have done. When there is no customer or loss in customer the employee will not have much work to do and this will result in them receiving little salary or even no payment from the business. A business might also not pay the employee if he or she takes a long break from work as the business might decide that they will hire someone else instead.<n><n>### Question: What is a positive effect one's spouse receives when someone else takes them as a partner? Choices: A: have more friends and family B: be happier C: get divorced D: no spouse E: get a best friend

The house will have 44 rooms, and each room will have between 1 and 10 windows.  Fred wishes the number of windows per room to average out to 5 and the number of rooms with 10 windows to average out to 1.  He would also like to be able to describe the number of rooms that have 8 windows with a single sentence. What is the maximum number of windows that would have to be removed from the house to be able to say that? (Bonus) Fred would also like the number of rooms with a specific number of windows to be as evenly distributed as possible. He is okay with the number being higher (though not much over 50%) than the number of rooms with between 1 and 5 windows.  What is the least amount of rooms that would have to have windows removed to satisfy this?<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the answer to this question by describing the data manipulation that could do it. Do not provide any code to solve the problem.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>#### Sample Inputs:<n>12, 32, 52, 64, 35, 10167, 52, -46, 1, 424, 25<n>#### Sample Outputs:<n>110, 21917, 7018<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Answer<n><n>Sample Outputs:<n>29917, 4918, -3145, 35004

If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:After attending school for twelve years what do you do? Choices:  A: inspiration B: much work C: boredom D: graduate E: degree<n><n>### Response:		(Write a response that appropriately matches the question with one of the choices).<n><n>*Input:After attending school, I choose to be ____. Choices:  A:"inspiration, much work, boredom", B:"degreed" C:"graduate", D:"boredom"<n><n><n>Input: How do you respond to your friends when they say that math makes you feel boredom? Choices: <n><n>Answer: The word I usually respond to them is "it's normal",<n> <n>Input: <n><n>Answer:(write a response that appropriately fits any of the following two options).If you are planning to learn more, you can find a source. What source? You can search through various resources. What kind of source? There are many sources in digital and physical formats. What kind? If you are not a computer lover, you can always find other sources other than digital sources. How? Reading books. Where can you find physical copies? Books stores. What do you need for an online source? Internet.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Lizards need the sun's heat to regulate their body temperature, this is why you'll see them still on what? Choices:  A: bushes B: dessert C: books D: heat lamps E: rocks<n><n>### Response:		E rocks<n><n>

How many are there in my family, if I am a boy?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: 12<n><n> ### Input:John is 20% more mature than his twin brother and he is half as old as his mother. If John’s brother is 25 years old and John is 32 years old, what is the age of their mother?<n><n>### Output:<n>Anna K, who is 47 years ago.<n><n>### Process : <n><n>1.  What is the age of John, his twin brother?<n>```<n>Age of brother : John<n>Twins Age = 20% : 20 ( )<n>Twins = 50% : 50 ( )<n><n>twins age = 25<n>```<n>2.` ` What is the age of their mom?<n>```<n>John 32 years<n>Twins Brother 25<n>Mom 32+2=34<n>```<n>If we add all the values we will get the answer<n><n>3. 27 years old

Is the dice biased or not?<n>### Response:Not at all.<n>### Instruction:Input:A box contains 15 cards numbered 1-15. One is removed at random. What is the probability that the card chosen is a multiple of 3?<n>### Response:"3 or 6"<n>### Instruction:#1-The total number of red marbles is three times the total number of blue marbles. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If a person is seeing new things, what do they most often feel? Choices:  A: curiosity B: excitement C: boredom D: wonder E: fear<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>How much does 33466670 in dollars?<n><n>### Response<n>Input 3346<n>Output 3,346,000<n><n>### Input 2<n>How much does 55599999 in dollars?<n><n>Output 5,559,990<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>In the game of golf, a par 3 is a hole that is 200 yards long.  You tee off one club more than the distance from the tee box, and try to achieve a par.  Each hole has a par value, and a golfer's score is calculated by getting that value or less from the hole.  If you can't get a par, you have a bogey or worse.<n><n>What is the easiest par 3 you can hit in golf?<n><n>### Instructon: <n>### Example<n>If the player gets a par, the final value of the score will be 5.  Scores must be whole numbers, positive or negative.  If the player is on the ninth hole, then they can calculate how many clubs will go in the bag.  All of this information is included in Player's Score.<n><n>For example, if Player A is at a 160 yard hole, and they play their driver from the 164-yard tee on the next hole and score a par, then they end up with an 18 hole score of 95.<n><n>### Inputs<n>Input: Bob plays a par 88 course.  He gets a 6 on the first hole.<n>Input: A 442 par game.  Player A gets a 4 on the second hole.<n>Input: The ninth hole 12 game has the largest par value of any par 3 game.<n>Input: On the 10th hole, the game is 58.  The player scores a bogey.<n><n>Output: 95<n><n>Input: Player A plays a par 3 game with a par value of 58.  She scores a par on the first hole, a par-4 on the second, a par on the third, a birdie on the fourth, and a par on the fifth.  She ends the day with a score

They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What part of the body are lips on? Choices:  A: mouth B: jars and all faces C: kentucky fried chicken D: hand E: human<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Its on their mouth if you ask me<n><n>### Detailed explanation<n>A lips is part of a mouth, which is found on every face but the head face.<n>

A: university B: College class C: Class room D: library E: classroom because college class requires 9am to 1pm, that is 8 hours a day. The library is open 24 hours, that is all day.<n><n>### Input Jim will buy 3 bags of cereal and each of the cereal bag would weigh 2 pounds. It cost 9.50c for each pound of cereal. Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		 ship's hold<n><n>### Explanation:  Ship's hold is more expensive than any other transportation but the fastest<n><n>### If the question is:<n>"How many pears did Jack buy? The answer is 180:<n>There are 32 oz in a pound.<n>1 lb of pears costs $2, and there are 180 pears in the box.<n>The box can hold two boxes.<n>1 box costs $75.<n>How much did Jack buy?<n>\<n>$\text{answere value=$2$.}$<n>### Explanations: A boat can transport small items quickly and it is more convenient than a truck. But it can only transport things that can sit on the boat. So it is faster but more expensive way to send small items.<n>### Solution:<n><img src="https://i.imgur.com/LUyP25O.png"><n><n>### Input2:  A club is going to have 5 more visitors than their current number of members. Choices: 1: scrambled eggs 2: french toast 3: potatoes 4: pancakes 5: pasta<n><n>### Response:`(1)`<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple answer question.<n><n>## Instructions:Write a response that appropriately answers the request.<n><n># Instructions:<n><n>The 1930 census showed that there were 141.1 million people living in the United States.<n><n>How many times larger was the U.S. population in 1930 than it was in 1820 (give your answer to the nearest ten million)?<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>The 2012 U.S. census states that the population is 311,591,917 people.  In 1820, as stated by Wikipedia, the US census for 1820 states 9,825,894 people lived in America.  Therefore, this data set is not linear. To solve in logarithms:<n><n>1820 = 9,826017,036<n><n>1930 = 141,101,548<n><n>In 1820 there were 0.983x10^6 people living in America.<n><n>We can convert this to log using the LN function:<n><n>`LN(9,826,018,685) = 3.72188164926398`<n><n>`LN($US population in 1990) - LN($US population in1820).`<n><n>`Rationalizing the denominator we get: 3.72250018479020`<n><n>`3.722 - 3.720 = 0.002`<n><n>So the answer is about 2 million off. This is due to error and rounding.<n><n>## References:<n><n>1. WolframAlpha.com (18.11.2021) <n>2. Wikipedia.org

Choices:  A: waterfalls B: underwater C: beach D: surface of earth E: river<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Explaination:<n>Three quarters of what? It must be an entire thing that could be covered. Thus choices E and B can be eliminated. The choice D might be a possibility, but that means the area of the ocean could be covered, which means the oceans are not flat. The surface area of the earth is approximately 9 billion square miles, with 71% of it water.<n><n>### Input:(1+sin(2t))+sin(3t)+(sin(4t)-sin(6t)) is equal to: Choices:<n><n>### Response:(i) 1-sin(2t)<n>(ii) 1+sin(2(1-t))<n><n>### Explain:<n>The question looks a bit complex, but this question can be reduced to finding the product of two functions instead of adding three equations. The product of a and sin(2t) is the sine function with the argument 2t+a. By using the identity sin(2x+y) = sin(2x)cos (y) – sin(y) cos (2x), we can express the above as the sum of two sums, where one expresses the second summation in terms of the first as in (I), and the other does the same as in (II). We now set a = 0, eliminating the other term, but adding sin(2(1-0)) = 1 to the right side. To finish, we just want to solve for t in the quadratic equation, which gives t = 0.<n><n>### Write a program that calculates total pay if a person has to paid 1 dollar if he is on time, and 5 dollars if he’s late.  Write an algorithm that calculates the amount of interest compounded daily.<n><n>### Response (1):<n>Input: A person is given $15 for each day they are on time and $5 for each day that they are late. How many dollars will he earn in a year?<n>Answer: 225<n><n>### Response 2:<n>Input: Fred must use a monthly loan, which has a 10% interest and he pays it by the end of the month. How much he spends 3 months after?<n>Answer: 94.5<n><n>### Explicit

Choices:  A: town B: conference C: bathroom D: theater E: train station<n><n>### Response:		What a tricky question.<n><n>#### When people want to watch a movie, they probably go see it at the **conference center**.<n><n>## Reasoning:<n><n>If the people are going to the town, the movie probably isn't that new anymore.<n>If the people are at the movie theater, there's a good chance they've already<n>seen it and are going to complain.<n>If the people go to the conference center, the movie seems new.<n>

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where would you buy a ticket to sit in a room with a lot of chairs facing the same direction? Choices:  A: conference B: theater C: building D: floor E: church<n><n>### Response:		D<n>- The only option that fits the description is in a church.<n><n>### Input:(2x)(3)<n>What does the multiplication symbol mean here?<n><n>### Response:(2)(3)<n>Multiplication is two times three which means it is eight by the way a times b equals b times a. And then it is addition of two integers. It is actually the sum of 3 two's which is 6.<n><n>### Challenge<n>Write the expressions a, b, c and d. One of the expressions is different than the others.<n>```<n>Answer: a=x2, b=x+y, c=z-w, d=15-u+17<n>```<n><n>### Challenge:A bag contains 6 blue balls, 5 white balls, and 1 green ball.  Two balls are randomly selected without replacement.  What is the probability of selecting a blue ball for both the samples if the number of blue balls is also the same?  The answer is 0.383333. What is the probability it will be a fraction?<n>```<n>Answer: 0.50<n>```<n><n>## Extra Help<n>### [Georgias State School of Law](http://www.law.gsu.edu/student-life/lawlibrary/exam-prep/multiple-choice-questions-and-answers.html)<n>### [Georgetown University Law Center](https://www.law.georgetown.edu/academics/jd-life/resources/academic-support/preparing-for-the-lsat/)<n>### [George Washington university](https://www.gwu.edu/~asc/LSATPreparation.cfm)<n>### [Harvard University](https://law.harvard.edu/research/study-groups/test-prep/)<n>### [Indiana University](https://lawschool.iu.edu/academicesupport/lsat/index.html)<n>

Choices:  A: grocery store B: refrigerator C: freezer D: plate E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the following task.<n><n>### Input<n>Wanting to avoid her groceries from spoiling, where did she put it?<n>Choices: A: grocery bokc<n>B: freezer<n>C: refrigerator<n>D: plate<n>E: her supermarket.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Input 1:In the second game of a 7-game series, how many times may both Bob and Alice have the game go to 11, 12 or 13 games?<n><n>### Answer:<n>The 1st game goes to either 11 or 12.<n><n>The 2nd game goes to either 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4 extra games.<n><n>The 3rd game goes to either 5, 6, 7, 8 or 9 extra games.<n><n>A: A: The game is over if it goes to 13.<n><n>B: B: The game is over after 5 extra games.<n><n>C: C: After 5 extra games, they play until 11, 20, 29, 38, or 47.<n><n>D: D: After both reaching 12 without a tie at 12, they keep playing until 13.<n>E: E: Both players play until 13.

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:In war, your primary method is combat, but your goal is to do what? Choices:  A: conquer opponent B: fight enemy C: join army D: kill E: terrible<n><n>### Response:		<n>    F: The answer is "Kill".<n><n>    F: The primary method is combat, and your goal is to kill the enemy.<n><n>    F: Fighting is the only method to kill enemy.

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The doctor recommended washing hands, what was being promoted? Choices:  A: jungle B: bamboo grove C: australian outback D: china E: child's book<n><n>### Response:		This is a good koala to pick, but this is an Australian koala and pandas are from China.  What they did was a mistake.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: The koala in the museum is a good choice.  The koala is a mammal, so it can be used in the Museum with other mammals.  However, the Museum should get a stuffed version of a panda.  Pandas are not native to Australia like koalas are.  Getting koalas for the museum is appropriate and they should not have made a mistake in getting a koala rather than a Chinese panda.<n><n>A: The koala in museum is a good choice because it can be used in other places in the museum.  The panda is not used in the museum because the panda is from China.<n><n>B: The koala is in a museum because it is large enough to be a pet in the house.  A panda would also work in a zoo.<n><n>C: The koala is from Australia, a panda is from China<n><n>D: The koala looks like it is from China, but the museum has more than koalas for pandas<n><n>E:: A koala and a panda will play with your child's books and the koala will try to eat it.  A koala and a koala will not play with each other.  A koala goes to a school and the panda will be a student at a school.  A koala can live under water.  A koala lives at the zoo and is happy there.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Response: The koala is a good choice for the museum but the museum needs a Chinese Panda instead of a koala.  Pandas are from China.  Koalas are not from China.  <n>

If you need help writing the job posting from the client, you can write it down here, and then follow it up with a detailed proposal for your employer using the text field provided as comment.<n><n>### Client:<n>John would like to post a full-time opening for a position as a Customer Experience Lead. The job will oversee the design and management of customer experience programs. The role reports to John, who is the Senior Director of Customer and Business Experience at a major bank. The ideal candidate will be experienced in managing customer experience and will have an ability to drive transformation and change by leveraging their skills and experience. The candidate should be an innovative thinker with exceptional communication skills. Candidates must demonstrate the ability to collaborate with stakeholders across multiple business units and the executive team. This role will also be responsible for building and managing a team of experts, developing organizational strategy, defining performance targets, and leading the design and delivery of programs to influence customers at the various touch points of their journey. The ideal candidate will have a passion for customer experience, experience in creating and managing metrics and insights program, and experience with research and analytics programs. They will also need to be proficient in customer segmentation and in using customer experience surveys, call monitoring, website analysis, and social media.<n><n>### Employer:<n>Joe would like to write a job posting for a Customer Experience Leader at a major bank. John is the senior director for customer and business experience. The role will oversee the design of customer experience programs and the management of these programs. This role will collaborate with stakeholder groups across multiple business units and with the executive team. It will be responsible for building and leading a team of experts whose job it will be to design customer experience initiatives that will meet performance targets. <n><n>### Job:<n>Customer Experience Lead - Oversees the design and management of the customer experience program  <n>Job Title:  <n>Customer Experience Leader  <n>Job Description:  <n>\* Provide oversight role for a customer experience program  <n>\* Lead a team of experts  <n>\* Build and lead an expert team

Choices:  A: toy store B: hall C: bathroom D: amusement park E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		Incorrect: Billy's mother did not yell at him because there was a stuffed animal where she tripped<n><n>### Input:-13 is twice the sum of -2 and 6. what is that sum?<n><n>### Response:-15<n><n>## Resources:<n>- https://github.com/michael-bryer/algorithms<n>- https://medium.com/the-codelord-s-guide-to-everything/the-10-commandments-of-recursion-part-1-9f0bd83e8fa6
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What are adult people usually expected to do? Choices:  A: shake hands B: own property C: pay bills D: smoke E: talk to each other<n><n>### Response:		A and B are true but C and D are false.<n><n>## Instructions:You will now work on a writing task.<n><n>### Writing task:<n>Write a one-page instruction that describes a task and appropriately completes the instruction.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>### Instructions:Write a one-page (450-500 word) instruction.<n><n>## Response:Write a response as the one provided in Chapter Two.<n><n>### Input (Part 1 of 2):Choose a sport that you have engaged in often for one complete week in the last 3 months. Using the provided example and your own choice of sport, write a one-page (300-340 word) instruction that describes a task (that you and the participants must do) and appropriately completes that task.<n><n>## Input (Part 2 of 2):Write a response as the response is provided in Chapter Two. <n><n><n># Solution<n><!-- Lecture slides --><n>## Instruction:Answer the question below in one paragraph (not one sentence). Use complete sentences.<n><n>### Question:What do you consider to be the single most important life skill that someone must learn? You have been asked to prepare a presentation that includes an introduction, a body with at least three points (subtopics) and a conclusion.<n><n>## Input:Choose a sport that YOU have engaged in at least once every week for one complete week in a 6-month period. For example, in six months, did you engages in soccer at least once a week every week for six months? If so, you could choose sports like soccer. You can answer this question orally or through pictures but be aware of your audience and the task that you set.<n><n>## Response for Instruction:Write a response as follows<n><n>### Instructor:Choose a sport. (Soccer, swimming, football, basketball.)<n><n>### Student:Write a one paragraph answer as follows:<n><n>##### I have played swimming for at least twelve times in a month and for two years, and I love it. I learned how to dive and how to swim the whole course in ten years and a half. I have earned a national swimming medal and a first national sport medal.<n><n>#### Student: Write a presentation using pictures.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Dan said that getting in line was the best choice because it would lead to what? Choices:  A: being ordered B: less confusion C: boredom D: standing in line E: have to wait for<n><n>### Response:		A<n>

Two minutes<n><n>2. Three months<n><n>3. Two decades<n><n>4. two years<n><n>5. 101 years<n><n>### Comment1:<n><n>## Test 2:<n><n>##### What does 65*X+3(X-6/2) mean?<n><n>1. (X-6/2)*65<n><n>2

Choices:  A: happiness B: sore muscles C: injury D: perfection E: errors<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Answer:<n>E: errors<n>#### Explanation:<n>Explanation:Baseball is a game where a single mistake can end your career. Errors are a stat that shows the amount of mistakes one has made in a game or season.<n><n>### Input:"The number of errors are equal to 5 % of the games a team has played" Can you solve for the letter"G" in the expression:"The number of games played is equal to 20% of the errors?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Answer:The number of games played equals 50<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>#### Answer:"The number of games the team has played" ChoiceA: The number of errors ChoiceB: G ChoiceC: The number of games played ChoiceD: The number of errors per game ChoiceE: The errors per game ChoiceF: The number of games the team played ChoiceG: None of these (none matches) ChoiceH: The games won (not an option in the choices provided) Choice I: The number of games lost (not an option in choices provided) <n><n><n>### Exercise: 8 - 10<n><n>#### Answer:"Fred plays video games for an average of 6 hours per week and watches TV for 8½ hours per week" Choices: Choice: A: Fred plays 45 minutes of video games and watches 2 games Choice: B: Fred plays 4 games of video games and watchs 9¼ hours of TV Choice: C: Fred plays 49 hours and 45 minutes of a video game Choice: D: Fred plays 6½ hours of a video game Choices: ChoiceE: Fred watches 4 games  and plays 3 hours of video/TV Choices: ChoiceF: Fred is playing an average of 4 hours per day of gaming ChoiceG: Fred plays on average 6 hours of video games and watch 8- 9 hours of TV ChoiceH: Fred plays 4 hours of videos games and watch 7½<n><n><n><n><n># [9/11/2018  [9/11 2018] - Assignment 3: The Language of Computation](http://hawaii.instructure.com/courses/1
