I couldn’t believe what a beauty the bride was! But the party crasher was her drunk ex-boyfriend! What was weird was that his ex-girlfriend had already gotten married herself 3 years earlier. How many years does this describe? Choices: 1:7 2:2 3: 5 years 4:12 5:10 years<n><n>### Response :3<n><n>### Input A: I was just sitting watching CNN a little while ago and was shocked to hear on the news that a certain music festival will be moving from a larger stadium to a smaller venue. They said it was because of increased demand.  But does increased demand alone explain the change?  This is a story for a music festival that only started 5 years ago called Coachella, now sells out in 40 minutes of going public with the lineup. But that’s only one side of the story!  To get to the real story, let’s look at the festival’s attendance over the last 5 years. The attendance for 2013 was about 80,000.  Let’s say the number of people attending has approximately quadrupled.  In 2013 it was 2x and in 2021 it was 4x.  So what can you say about the relationship between these two events using a graph?<n><n>### Response B:<n>##### It is a Parabola with a positive y-intercept and increasing y-values<n><n>### Input B:<n>  A)I heard that there is going to be a large amount of unrest in my town this weekend!  I am worried there will be police in the streets and it will be tough to get any sleep.  It might even be tough to go outside on the weekend! What should I do?<n>##### I will just ignore it and wait to see what happens!<n><n>### Response C:<n>##### Bingo! The police are planning an operation to get rid of the problem, but don’t want to risk public safety. The police said “The riot on Saturday will be more like a firework display

Write code that:<n>### 1. Reinitializes the array to 15,<n>### 2. Increments array value by 5 whenever it sees the 8 in the string and then prints the string,<n>### 3. Prints array value and then increment by 4 and then prints the array value incremented,<n>### 4. Prints the array value and initializes the array value to 10.<n><n>for (int i = 14; i <= n; i++)<n>            {<n>            if (data.CharacterEquals('8'))<n>                data.Character = (char)((data.Character - '0') % 10) + '0';<n>            else<n>            {<n>                if (data.Position == 16 || data.Position == 17)<n>                {<n>                    Console.WriteLine("{0} {1} {2} ", i, data.Character, data.String);<n>                }<n>                else<n>                {<n>                     Console.WriteLine("{2}", data.Character, i, data.String);                             <n>                }<n>                data.Position++;<n>            }<n>            }<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program that performs the following tasks.<n><n>- Given the name of a continent, find the country with the closest population to that continent's population.<n><n>E.g. if africa's and europe's population was 400.5 million and 745.6 million respectively. 20223 would have been closest<n><n>### The population of each continent<n><n>Australia: 23,191,389(49%)<n>Europe: 745,664,935(49%)<n>Asia: 4,175,001,580(16%)<n>Africa: 400,515,400

Choices:  A: coffee B: throw up C: food D: getting drunk E: wine<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Instruction: 4.0**<n><n>### Input & Output:<n><center><img src="Screenshot.png" alt="Input" width="50%" height="50%" /></center><n><n>### Explanation:<n>In this problem, the word `Input` means the `input` statement.<n><n>In this problem, Brad ordered breakfast and the choices for him to drink include beverages such as coffee and wine. However, there is an implication of the sentence that Brad will not drink too much since he can throw up. There are also two choices that he could throw up, therefore, he will not drink. Since the only options he could drink is coffee and wine, we can just say that Brad drinks coffee after eating breakfast without throwing up.<n><n><center><img alt="Output" src="Screenshot2.png" width="50%"></center><n><n>## Code<n>```python<n>from functools import reduce<n>n = 1<n>k = 3<n>while True:<n>    if n * 2 > k:<n>        n = n - 1<n>    else:<n>        break<n><n>k = 2<n>while True:<n>   if  k * 2 > =n:<n>       k = k - 1<n>   else:<n>       n = n + 1<n>  <n>print(n * k)<n>```<n>

If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:He made another call, he did this all day hoping people would what well to his offer? Choices:  A: hang up B: respond C: contact D: answer E: attracting ducks<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions: <n>The person who is being talked to will always say or ask for something before putting forward a request. The person has no real intention of making the other person do something. The person is just calling in to say "Hello." They are calling simply to let you know they called/are calling.<n><n>### Input 2<n>He made another call, they did this all day hoping the people would like their offer. Choices: A: hang up B C: contact D contact E: attracting duks<n><n>### Response<n>B and D, the other two choices would be more in line with saying that you are "calling in", because of the word "people" in those statements<n><n>### Instuction 2:<n>1. The person who is being talked is making a point to get help. They are asking or calling for help. They are requesting assistance in getting something 2. The person needs to be directed to someone who can help. The person is only trying to get in contact with the person they need help from.<n><n>### Response to Instuction 2<n>Both the above are good, but if there are any people that need help, than A and B would be more appropriate.<n><n>###Input 3:<n><n>Some customers have some complaints and they are being irrational. It doesn't take you much time to talk with them and make things right. There is no doubt we will attract more good customers with our service level. Choices:  A. Too bad I've been busy lately B. Not all customers are like that C. I feel sorry for the situation D, E, F)<n><n>###Response 3<n>Too bad I've taken to busy lately will sound better for the situation.<n><n>###Instruction 3<n>1. The speaker is trying too solve a problem with the listener. They are trying to get the listener to share ideas or to help solve the problem in some way or another. 2. The listener is trying in some way, too help the speaker solve the problem at hand. <n><n>###Response to Instuction 3<n>Choices C&D both sound good and the statement makes sense for the listener.

One kilograme of nuts will cost 12 dollars and one kilogramme of dried fruit will cost 8 dollars. How much does he spend on their purchases?<n><n>### Response:[ ] His purchases cost 52 dollars.<n><n>### Output:<n>Explanation (Answer + Explanation): Adam bought 3 kilo of nuts and 3 k of dried fruits. 3 k + 3 k = 6 k total. 1 k is 25 % of the total.  1 k for 6 k will be 20 %  20% of 6 is 20  20 + 20 - 6 = 56<n><n>Explanation (Choice + Explanation): Everyday,James works out for 4 hours. He will lift weights for 3 of the four hours.  So 1/3 of his total work will be lifting weights.  1/2 of the 4 hours will be spent on warm-ups and cardio  1/3 of the warm-ups of cardio and 1/3 of lifting weights will be used for warm-ups and cardiio.  <n>The total amount of all this will be <n>time + warm-ups of cardiio and lifting weights + warm-up<n>Answer: 8 hours<n><n>---<n><n>### Input2:Every day Tom drinks 6 12-oz. cans of soda and 32 ounces of water  for a total of 6.5 pounds. The rest will be consumed for 5 days, which is 50.  So the total soda consumed in 7 would be 60 pounds.<n><n>### Response5:[ ] The total amount of liquid he

What is the probability that they win the next 5 games in a row?<n><n>### Response:(1) B, (2) A<n><n>###Input: The probability that a randomly picked number is odd is 0.7. Find the probability that the number selected is odd and greater than 2<n><n>###Response:C<n><n>###Input:(1) Calculate the probability of being the winner. (2) A girl got a scratch card.  If she got a ticket after losing, what is the probability that she will get to the top 10 in the next 10 games (i.e. win in the next 1, 2, 3…10 games?)<n><n><n>###Response:(1) A, (2) B<n><n>###Input : (1) The probability that a randomly selected numbered student will be chosen as the best is 0.8. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:You can hear testimony of how spirituality changes lives when you do what? Choices:  A: go to church B: appear in court C: watch soap operas D: paying attention E: go into court<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Inputs:What is the weight of one bottle of water? Choices: 1. ​9 pounds​ 2. ​12 pounds 3. ​15 pounds​ 4. ​17 pounds​<n><n>### Response 1:<n>12 pounds<n><n>### Which of the following would be an efficient way to solve this problem? Choices: A. Average the weights B. Multiply each weight by its position in the group C. Add the weights of the different weights of each<n><n>We can use addition. Because we're only calculating the weight of a bottle of water one time, so there's no need to subtract it later, or multiple it.<n><n>Because we're just calculating a new value on an already calculated value.<n><n>### InputHow many bottles of water are sold from the supermarket? Choices:  A: roof B: school C: beach D: closet E: garage<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:Analyze the input and output above the table to complete the table.<n><n>### Table Header:<n>P = Purchase<n>M = Money<n>S = Total<n>C = City<n>Z = Zone<n><n>### Input<n>Purchase   Money   Total   City   Zone   Notes<n>-   -   -   -   --   --   -<n><n>### Input 1<n>-   Purchase   Money   $      C     Zone   -<n><n>## Output<n>-   -   $    -   -   -      -     0<n><n>### Input Output Analysis:<n>Purchase 6 gallons of milk and $30 worth of meat.  C = Chicago and Zone = 93-45<n><n>### Response<n>-   C = Chicago<n><n>## Outcome<n>-   Total cost: $305<n><n>### Instructiion:<n>Given the price of a product, complete the following table.<n><n>## Input<n>Price   Cost<n>-   -   --<n><n>## Input 1<n>Price   Cost   Note<n>-   $    -     C = Chicago, Zone = 93<n><n>## Output<n>Total cost: $308<n><n>### Input Observation<n>Input 1 is the same as input 2<n><n>### Instrument 3<n>-   37   $  -   -   -<n><n>## Input 2     8    $   *<n>-   $    ---<n><n>### Observation<n>Instrument 2 gives me a second instance of input 1 that is different only by the price and output. The output for input 2 is the same as the output for input 1, both being 308. This tells me that I don't really need input 2<n><n>The solution is 4x7 = 28, and 2x7 = 14. 4x7 + 2x7 =42<n><n>### Solution<n>-   C = chicago, zone = 94, 42 dollars, 28 gallons<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Based on the following input, complete the table.<n>Number of Pounds  x .30   =   Cost<n><n>### Input      -    -   -   --<n>### Input:   1

Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n><n>### Response:		Answer: Option A - A, if you did well on a test, you might get a'see work' as a what? See answer below and the correct answer to the question below.<n><n>Option - Correct Answer:<n><n>Option - Wrong Answer:<n><n>### Input <n><n>- The sum of the squares of the first 500 positive integers is 1050500 square feet. How many square feet are there in all?<n><n>### Instructions<n>- The next line will contain 500 space separated integers. The values of these integers will range in the interval between [0...500], inclusive.<n>- Print a single line that contains the sum of the square of all values.<n><n>### Expected Output <n><n>- The next line of the input will contain the value 8, 751, 441, 153, 5, 66, and 38<n>	<n>### Sample Input <n><n>5 9 13 17 42 65 66 55 7<n><n>### Sample Output <n><n><n><n>### Solution<n><n>Answer: Use this snippet to make sure your inputs are within the expected range (this will handle the first and last digits).<n><n>Inputs: [0...50, -1, +1]<n>Outputs: [ 500 * x * x]<n><n>The final call is `reduce`:<n><n>```javascript<n>let solution= input.reduce (<n>(prev,cur) => {<n>    let sum = prev;<n>    if(cur>=0){ sum+= cur * cur;  }<n>    else if(cur<=-1){ sum+= 10;  }<n>    return sum;<n>},0<n>);<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>The sum of the squares of 100 positive integers is N. How many square units are there altogether?<n><n>### Response<n>Option A - I have no idea!<n>Option B - The sum of the squares: 851,600<n>Option C - The answer is 851,700, which is the sum of the numbers being squared.<n>Option D - 851,599,999<n>Option E - 851601<n>

Choices:  A: tennessee B: inside joke C: grassy field D: the forrest E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>We can eliminate answer choices A and C because the fox will always be able to make a run for it. Answer choices B is a bad pun. No one would be likely to catch a fox in an inside joke. Finally, Answer choice E is just a list of a bunch of countries.<n><n>Our answer has to be Option D. The fox is going to be caught in a field.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>A friend of mine loves fishing.  She goes fishing every weekend in the summertime.  She is trying to figure out her total catch amount. Write a function that appropriately completes to task.<n><n>### Task:Eight people entered a contest to win a prize. In order to be eligible, each person had to complete the contest. The contest asked for a question to be answered in 500 words or less. The winning question was chosen and awarded the prize. All of the participants completed the question and the answers were read aloud to the judges. In no particular order, the judges awarded 6 silver medals and 2 gold medals to the question answers. The numbers of silver and gold medals are known. Only the names of the people and the number of gold and silver medals awarded to each are known. Which person won the bronze medal and what were the first- and second-place prizes?<n><n>### Answer<n>There is no other person other than Alice who got a bronze medal. Alice also was the only one who did not won any gold or silver. First place prize was a car and second was a boat.<n><n>```<n>var gold = [5,3],<n>    silver = [6,1];<n>```<n><n>```<n>function getWinnings(input) {<n>    var [winner, gold, silver1, silver2] = input;<n>    if(!winner) throw new Error("No winner!");<n>    var [firstName, secondName, thirdName, fourthName, fifthName, sixthName, seventhName, eightName] = winner;<n>    var [firstPlace, secondPlace, bronze] = [firstName, sixthName, secondName];<n>    var [goldMeds, silverMeds, bronzeMed] = [gold, silver1];<n>    return {<n>        win: true,<n>        firstName: firstPlace,<n>        secondName: secondPlace,<n>        thirdName: bronze,<n>        fourthName: goldMeds > 0? "Gold" : null,<n>        fifthName: firstName == bronze? "Silver" : firstName == bronze?  "Bronze"

Music shop would be the best.<n><n><n>### Inputs:<n>Input:  A family is packing a vacation.  They decide to pack in groups of 20 pounds, with all of the clothes being packed in the first group and the souvenirs being packed in the last group.  The family has one suitcase, and they don't want to keep items in the suitcase they haven't used yet, so the items will be packed into the group of items that have been used.  The family wants to maximize the total number of items in the suitcase while adhering to this rule. How many items can fit in the suitcase if they pack in this way?<n><n>### Input Types:int,int<n><n>### Input 1:27<n><n>### Response 1: 16<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Expected Output:<n>27<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: James went to the store to buy tomatoes. There were 5 types of tomtoes for sale. The prices were:<n><n>$3.10 a pound for plum tomtoes<n><n>$4.60 a pound for regular tomtoes<n><n>1.50 a pound for beefsteak tomtoes<n><n>3.80 a pound for cherry tomtoes, 2.00 a pound for pear tomtoes<n><n>How many pounds of tomtoes did he buy?<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write the program by using the function to solve the problem.<n>```js<n>function solution(x) {<n>    if (typeof x === "number" || x % 1!== 0) return false;<n>  var result = 0;<n>  for (let i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {<n>    result += x[i] * 2;<n>  }<n>  return result % Math.pow(10, 2) === 0;<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Instrucions<n>Instrucions:<n>Write a function to reverse a string, if the string is empty, do nothing.<n>```js<n>// Examples of correct reversals:<n>1

How long does it seat?<n><n>Answer: A chair can seat two people with a distance of 10 inches between each person. It can seat 8 people.<n><n>Input: A cake has three large pieces and two smaller pieces. How many total pieces does the cake have?<n><n>Answer: The large pieces take up a third of the cake. Therefore, 3 * (1/3) = 2 large pieces<n>Also, the small pieces take up half of the cake remaining. Therefore, 4 * (1/2) = 2 small pieces

Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		 The loose dictionary is on a shelf.<n><n>### Input :A grocery store has two types of coffee beans, regular and organic. For every 10 bags of organic coffee beans the store sells, 23 bags of regular beans are sold. What percentage of the store's sales are organic coffee beans?<n><n>### Response : The percentage of the store'​s sales that is organic coffee is 23 / 100 = 0.23 or 23%.<n>

Choices:  A: jar B: stick to fingers C: beehive D: stick to fingers E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		Honey is sold in stick to fingers are cheaper as compared to the jars and beehives are for the ones having their own apiaries.<n><n>### Input : I am looking to buy hive bees right from an apiary. Where should I go? A : Jar B : stick to fingers C : farmer's market D : Beehive E : stick to fingers<n><n>### Response : I need Beehive as I have my own Apiary, farmer's market and jam are out of my budget and stick to fingers has more harmful effects on your health hence not suggested for long term use.<n><n>### Output : Farmer's market. <n><n>### Input(A) : There are 500 penguins living in the Antarctic. They are all exactly the same size and identical in every way, except for one characteristic: they have different colored bands around it's legs. How many different color bands on their legs are there?<n><n>### Output (B) : 10,000<n><n>### Input (C) : How many ways are there to select two children from a group of 8?<n><n>### Response (C): There are 8C2, 4 ways<n><n>### Input  : Every employee at the R&D division must test their product twice before they send it out for sale. The department manager tests the product in the first round if there are any problems. He then assigns a second task force to test the product to look for other errors. Every product goes through three rounds of testing on average before it is sold. You think there are 100,000 defects in a product during testing, and the defect rate is the same on all products during the three rounds. How many products must the manager test in the first round to have at least 1000 defects?<n><n>### Input Codes:<n><n>### Input Rounds:  a:0 b:1 c:2 d:3<n><n>### Response Rounds:<n><n>### b:2 c:4 d:3<n><n># Test Question<n><n>### Input Number of Rounds: 1<n><n>### Response Code:<n><n>### a:0 b:2 c:2 d:1<n><n>### Input Code Number of Rounds:<n><n>1<n>

Choices:  A: botanical garden B: doctor's office C: in a sea D: public place E: arboretum<n><n>### Response:		<n>***<n>Input: A; Output: 860<n><n>Input b: A; Output: A<n><n>Input c: B; Output: B<n><n>Input d: B; Output: C<n><n>Input e: B; Output: D<n>```python<n>'''<n><n><n>def solution(task_input, a):<n>    for choice in task_input.strip().splitlines():<n>        answer = "Choice " + str(a) + ". "<n>        for choice in a:<n>            if answer.isdigit():<n>                try:<n>                    choice = int(choice)<n>                    answer += str(choice)<n>                        break<n>                except ValueError:<n>                    pass<n>        else:<n>            answer += "Not a choice."<n>        print(answer)<n>```<n><n><n>def answer(task_input):<n>    def solution(task_input):  # function defined in instruction<n>        for choice in task_lines.strip().splitlines(True):  # splitlines returns newlines as strings (empty string)<n>            answer = "Choice "<n>            for choice in a:  # answer.isdigit() returns true if answer string starts with a digit (eg. 233.456...)<n>                if answer.isdigit() and answer[0].isdigit():  # if answer is in num form, try to convert it to int<n>                    try:<n>                        a_num = int(answer)  # int(x) converts x (choice.name) to int<n>                        answer = answer.strip()  # answer stripped from leading and trailing whitespaces including tabs and new lines<n>                            break<n>                    except ValueError:<n>                answer += str(choice).strip()<n>                else:<n>                    answer += 'Not a choice. '<n>        try:<n>            answer = int(answer)<n>            print(answer)<n>        except ValueError:<n>            pass<n>```

He was even eating faster after the salad had come. He finished his meal in 10 minutes. How much time did it take for Ferdinand to eat the bread?<n>### Response (1):Ferdie had already eaten the corn as FAST as he could then he kept on eating the bread faster than before, he finished eating his meal in 7 minutes<n><n>### Input(2)Following instructions below:<n>1. When a car is driving at 60 miles per hour its speedometer read 2,400.<n>2. While driving at 60 mph, the speedometer reads 2,403.<n>3. Write an expression to represent (the result of) this problem.<n><n>How many miles did the car travel?<n><n>### Response (2):The car's speedometer always went up by a certain amount(say by a number of 3) while driving at 60mph, then the new speedometer number(say 2,406)will always be the actual distance covered in miles while the number of times 2,402 is equal to number of hours it took for the car to travel 60 miles.  So, the actual distance it went while driving at 6pm is 60(x,402=3x,405=4x,406). so it went 240 miles.<n><n>### Task:<n>The cost is $12 per ticket for seats that are good. Choices: A - 40, B - 45, C - 65, D - 75, E - 180<n><n><n>### Answer : E<n><n><n>### Explanation : Because you are trying to find the total number of miles he drives, so he is either driving to or from the beach. So if he is driving to the beach, it will only be half the time. If he is driving back, it will be a full trip.<n><n>### Examples<n>Adam drives to the beach. He drives back home.<n>A -> 40, B -> 45<n><n>Adam drives to beach, drives back home, then drives to the beach again.<n>A -> 80, B -> 90<n><n>### Adam drives to beach, drives home, then drives back.<n>A -> 110, B -> 115<n><n>## Input: How much does Adam pay for his apartment per week?<n><n>## A):<n>400<n><n>## B):<n>500<n><n>## C):<n>650<n><n>## D):<n>250<n><n>## E):<n>350<n><n>## Answer:<n>C<n><n>Adam needs shelter for 4 nights a week for a month. That’s 16 weeks in a year. The total cost per year is thus 16 times the weekly cost. This yields 640 in the C choice.<n><n>Input: Adam runs 8 miles to school each day. Choices:  A: orchestra B: school band C: music store D: opera house E: home<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is'school band'.<n><n>### Justification:<n>1. The choices do not make sense.<n>2. Bass clarinet is not something that is typically available at a music store, so the correct answer should be'school.' The same thing can be said about 'home,' as bass clarinets can be easily damaged or need to be cared for much more frequently than instruments such as violins or cellos. <n>3. At this time, what was the maximum number of customers expected to walk through their door?]<n><n>### Response:[The answer is 180 which is from a combination of calculating all possible ways at which the customers can enter the the total of all possible combinations. The question only mentions that there are 2000 sq meters in the dining room so it would be 1000 times 2 so this would make the total number of possible customers per day 2000 times 10 for a total of 20,000 customers possible. Then to start with the inventory we can think of every possible option that can happen with a person or a customer as one unit and just see what the total number of possible units we have. This would give us the option of either a 8/8 combination with 8 units, a 7/9 with 7 units, 7/7 with 7 units, etc. and 5/10 with 10 units. Also one could add that in the end of the day Jack would do the dishes so there would be 0 possible dishes to dish and one could calculate the number of combinations of 0 and 1 for customers. The answer would be 20000 combinations with 5 combinations of 0 and also 1 combination of 1. Adding this this would

If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:He had a hard time finding the room on his schedule, it was on the second floor and he got lost in the very large what? Choices:  A: school B: office building C: house D: hotel E: centre<n><n>### Response:		On his schedule, it was not on the second floor, it was on the first floor.<n><n>### Input/Response: He had a hard time finding a room on his schedule, he was lost in a large? Choices:  A: solidifying B: melting C: getting cold D: feeling cold E: skin rash<n><n>### Response:		If the ground is getting wet, it means that it’s raining and the rain is making the ground wet. The solidifying could be referring to the ground becoming frozen or the ground solidifying due to the temperature.  The possible choices are A, B, and C.<n><n>### Inputs:How many cubic feet are there in 1 cubic yard? Choices: A: 1 B: 4 3 C:4 6 D: 4 3 5<n>### Response:1 Cubic yard is 27 cubic ft.<n><n>### Response : How do you know that you should add these numbers?<n>###  Input:27 + 82 = 109<n>###  Response:  A: The sum of the whole numbers is 109.<n>###  B: The difference between addends is 109 the sum of the whole numbers.<n>###  C: When you add the number of the 27 and the 82 the sum would equal the whole number which is 109<n><n>27 + 85 = 112<n>30 + 60= 92<n><n>if u think about it the sum is the first number of the next number or the difference is 19<n><n>### Input:(A) A square has an area of 40 square inches. A circle is 12 inches in diameter. The perimeter of the square is 20 square inches. Which figure has a perimeter closer to 20 square inches?<n><n>### choice :B) both have perimeter closer to 40 square inches<n><n>### Input:) A dog is walking along the side of a lake that is 12 inches deep. It sniffs at a spot on the bank 6 feet away from the lake. What is the water depth from that point?<n>### choice : B) the dog is 6 inches from the water<n><n>### Input : I can fit 16 pieces of fruit in a 5-gallon bucket. How many pieces of fruit fit in a 10-gallon bucket?<n><n>### Choice : B the bucket has a total capacity of 10 gallons 1 cup = 1 liter (10 gallons)<n><n># 10<n><n>### Input :-A

The choice that's least relevant to a shopping bag for groceries (choice _E_) is A, followed by B, C, and D in that order.<n><n>### Justification:<n>```<n><n>### Instructors Note:<n><n>### Question:<n>If you have a task you think would be good to include, please let us know and send us an appropriate sample question for that task.<n><n>### Sample Questions:<n>1. If a number is __________ of an integer, it is equivalent to the integer without considering the decimal part.<n>2. A bird costs between 0 and100, inclusive, <n>exclusive and the user is purchasing a birdhouse and ten birds. The birdhouse price can be anywhere between zero and two hundred <n>inclusive and the cost of ten birds is between zero and one hundred exclusive. Output: Find the total cost of the birdhouse and birds. If the <n>cost of the birdhouse is greater than its cost, the birdhouse is not included in the total."<n>```<n><n>### Run code<n><n>```<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <iomanip><n><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main()<n>{<n>    //Input the birdhouse price <n>    int birdhouse;<n>    cout << "Enter the price of the birdhouse between 0 and 199, inclusive" << endl;<n>    cin >> birdhouse;<n><n>    //Input the number of birds that you are buying <n>    int bird = 0;<n>    cout << endl << "Enter the number of birds between 0 and 99, exclusive" << endl;<n><n>    cin >> bird;<n><n>    //Check the birdhouse price and bird number inputted <n>    if (birdhouse<bird)<n>    {<n>    cout << "Invalid Input "<< endl;<n>    exit(EXIT_FAILURE);<n>    }<n>    else if (birdhouse >= bird || bird <= 0)<n>    { <n><n>    cout << "The birdhouse is too expensive" << endl;<n>        return 1;<n>    }<n><n>    //Input Birdhouse Price<n>    cout<< "Price of Birdhouse is " << birdhouse << endl;<n><n><n>    //Store birdhouse price<n>    double price = birdhouse;<n><n><n><n><n><n>    //Input bird price<n>    cout << "Price of the bird between 0 and 79, inclusive"  << endl;<n>    // Input

Choices:  A: alabama B: louisiana C: south carolina D: arkansas E: mountains<n><n>### Response:		The answer is D. Arkansas is a state located in the southern United States, as well as being the home of its capital and largest city, Little Rock. It is the home of the Dardanelle, the Buffalo River, the Razorback River, and the Arkansas River. Arkansas is one of the country's most mountainous regions, with the Ozarks located southeast of the river. The highest and lowest places in the United States are found in these mountains.<n>The state's nickname, the “Natural State,” gives a good insight into the state's natural beauty, which is well-known around the country. The state is home to numerous hiking trails, including the Pinnacle Mountain State Park in Little Rock, the Ozark National Forest nearby and Hot Springs National Park and Hot Springs Mountain Tower further north in Arkadelphia.<n><n><n><n>### Input：How many hours does Emily spend on her homework each day, given she spends 1 hour less than half the time she spends on her homework every week?<n>	<n>### Response：The answer is A. If you divide 4 hours by 1/2, you get 8 total hours. In other words, Emily works for 8 hours, less than 9 hours. The time is 9 hours. This gives us the answer of 9 hours.<n><n>##### Answer<n>		(A) 9 hours<n><n>### Instructions：Answers the questions.<n>### Demos：Answers the question.<n><n>## Input：Brian invested $3,000 to open a retail store. When the driver finds the tire is flat, he fills it with 6 pounds of air.  How does he know he has enough air?<n><n>### Choices for Question A<n><n>> Choice A. He has measured the air pressure in the tire and found the pressure to be at least 27 psi. He has the appropriate amount of air when he fills to 33.2 psi.<n><n>> Choice B. The driver will have the appropriate amount of air if the tire can hold that much without the air leaking out.<n><n>> Choices C and D are incorrect.<n><n>### Answer:<n>A<n><n>## Instructions:Answer each multiple-choice question below.<n><n>There are three types of triangles: equilateral, scalene, and isosceles.<n><n>## Questions<n><n>### Instructin: Choose and type the correct answer.<n><n>### Choice<n><n>The first question is how can you tell if it is an isosceles or equilateral triangle.<n><n>### Answers<n><n>### Choose and type the response that matches the question.<n><n>## Choices<n><n>### Choiche: A: _____ and the square root of 2 are very close in terms of their ratio.<n><n>### A or B:<n><n>### Choicestype the response that matches the Question.<n><n>## Question<n><n>## Instrucions: Choose and type your response.<n><n>## Risk and Return<n><n>### Risk<n><n>The _______ of the investment will not only influence how the investment will grow but also will influence whether you will find the investment attractive.<n><n>### Return<n><n>The _____ of the investment is the amount of ______ that you expect to earn during the time that you have invested the funds.<n><n>### Reward<n><n><n><n>### Rate of Return<n><n>The ____ _______ is used to ______.<n><n>### Chooses<n><n>##

Choices:  A: mouth B: can C: human D: snake E: kentucky fried chicken<n><n>### Response:		If the choices are A and B, then that answer is B. C, if it were a living thing, it would have some way to ingest food. D, if it were a snake, it would not have the ability to chew its food. E, in this instance, the answer would probably be D, but in others a human mouth would be correct.<n><n>### Input :What has ears, but cannot hear? Choices: human A kentucky fried Chicken B. A radio C. an earring D. a tree<n><n>### Response : If the choices are E or D, then the answer is D. Because a tree can hear through sound waves, as can a radio.<n><n>###Input : How can you add two apples and two apples? Choices : A.  two six apples B. Five hundred percent apples C. A hundred percent apples<n><n>###Response : If the choices are A, the answer would be a hundred percent apples, since adding two and multiplying would not yield the same quantity.<n><n>###Instruction:Answer the following multi choice question.<n><n><n>###Input: The number is 162. She said "Good morning, I am playing a life or death game with my grandfather today. You must stand by the window, so that you may be able to see and hear everything, but you must never disturb the game, no matter who is in danger." He kept his promise, and never spoke to the old man.<n>In the game, the old man played aggressively and attacked frequently. The old women defended against all of the attackers. She was losing. Just when the old women looked like she was going to lose, The old man, looked up, and said "There's somebody outside." The old women turned around and saw the little boy. She yelled "You are in the wrong room. The king and queen are just the other side of the door, and you are in the wrong room." "Don't tell my grandfather!" cried the boy. "We must tell my grandfather at once. He can only lose by getting up from his seat," said the old man. Quickly the old man went into the room. He was the king. If I want 4 pizzas I would pay:<n><n>$ 10 x 1 + $ 2 x 3 = $ 10 (pizza) + $ 6 (extra pizza) = $ 16<n><n>The best option is to buy 4 pizzas, as the cost is $ 7 per pizza and they will cost a total of 7 x 4 = 28 dollars. This option is clearly the worst.<n><n>### Input:[{'s': 'A', 'g': 2,'e': 8,'o': 4,'n': 14}, {'s': 'B', 'g': 16,'e': 16,'o': 14,'n': 2}]<n><n>### Response:[{'s':'A', 'g':8,'e':14,'n':10}, {'s':'B', 'g':12,'e':12,'n':8}]<n><n>My favorite type of entertainments are roller coasters and ferrries. This statement was given in the beginning. So an error would occur if another statement is given that contradicts the previous statement.<n><n>### Input Explanation:<n>In this case, we need to take a decision about the following four statements.<n><n>### Which statement is true given the context of this example?<n>A:  movies<n>B:  theatre<n>C:  cabaret<n>D:  conference<n>E:  Meeting<n><n>The statement 'displayed the people on the huge scree' makes it clear that either the 'display' was a video or the video was displayed on a screen. So'movies' is the answer.<n><n>### Explanation of Questions:<n><n>### There is no explanation of this question.

How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What business has a tower to transmit signals? Choices:  A: city B: toronto C: radio station D: roger that E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>The business would be a radio station because towers are used to transmit signals.<n><n>### Input<n>Dave has a job in maintenance at the radio station but also sells air time at the radio station.   When Dave sells time, he gets 3 dollars per hour for every hour he sells for the advertisers.  How much does Dave earn in a month if he works one day more this month than last month?<n><n>### Response<n>Dave would earn an additional 3 dollars per hour he worked as maintenance at the radio station.  Then he would get another 3 dollars per hour if he sells any air time over what he sold last month.  If he worked one day more this month then he would also earn 3 dollars per hour on the additional day.  As a result of him selling more time and working more days, Dave would make 17 dollars per hour this month.<n><n>### Output:<n>>What is  the difference between number 17 and number 18?<n><n>### Input :How much did he earn in a month overall?<n><n>### Output :3 times 17<n><n>

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What do people who are speech therapists do? Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		E is correct.<n><n>### Inputs: The last two terms of the arithmetic sequence are 4 and −2. Find the first term.<n><n>### Response : −3 is the correct answer.<n><n>### Task: Fill in the blank.<n><n>### The answer: There are six letters in the word pencil, each of which is different from all the others.<n><n>### Answer: In the word pencil (which contains the letters p, e, c, l, i, and s), each of the letters is different from the rest.<n><n>### Difficulty: Easy.<n><n>### Conclusion: <n>### If the word has an even number of letters: There are x letters in the word; each letter is different from all the rest.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:He had been doing favors for everybody at work, it was frustrating not getting any what for it? Choices:  A: let down B: respect C: illness D: satisfaction E: gratitude<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately continues the dialog using one of the phrases mentioned.<n>If no phrasal verb is appropriate, use the verbs of the original question.<n><n>## Example<n><n>#### Dialog:<n>Jane: I went to a concert the night before last.<n>Jim: Was it worth it?<n>Jane: Heck yes! The performer put on one hell of a show. She's as good as any I've ever seen, so she is.<n><n>#### Response to Jane:<n>A. It was an absolute pleasure to attend the concert.<n>B. The performer put on a hell of a show it was.<n>C. He's just as good as she is, that is.<n>D. She's one heck of a performer, I must say.<n>E. I've never seen anything like it before, let alone a hell of a show.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What did the business require of everyone walking into their store? Choices:  A: wear shoes B: learn C: hope for peace D: have a great day. E: do well<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n><n><n>### Different Types of Sentences<n><n>A sentence is a piece which contains a complete clause. Different types of sentences include<n><n>**Declarative Sentence**: A declarative sentence asserts a state of affairs/fact and conveys a message. <n><n>**Interrogative Sentence**: An interrogative sentence asks a question and expects the reader to answer that question.<n><n>**Negative Sentence (or Contradictory):** If the sentence includes "not", then it is considered as the negative sentence.<n><n>**Comparative Sentence**: If a sentence contains comparing two things and expresses their relations, the sentence is called the comparative sentence.<n><n>**Complex Sentence**: A complex sentence consists of an independent and a dependent clause.<n><n>**Simple Sentence**: If the sentence contains one independent clause, then it is called a simple sentence.<n>

How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What could you put a table in if you want the table to be in your house? Choices:  A: library B: demonstration C: corner D: football ground E: rug<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>A table is very useful at home, and people usually put them in the dining room, which they use to sit and eat with their families. If there was no dining room, then people would put the table in their living room. This is because people can use it for playing board games, or even for setting a TV atop of the table.<n><n>### Feedback:<n><n>- The task asks whether the table could be in the house. Since a table by definition is in the house, then putting it somewhere else makes no sense.<n>- There are five choices so the correct answer is either B or E since A, C, D are nonsensical.<n>- The first two choices are incorrect because a table in a library makes no sense.  A library has too many books to fit a table.  Also, the library is a place for education and a table cannot be used for this<n>- The third choice is incorrect because we are specifically trying to determine whether the table can be in the house.  We are not trying to determine where else it can be put.<n>- The fourth choice is incorrect because a rug does not really allow you to play a board game on it, nor does it really allow you to put anything else on it, nor does a rug allow you to put a table on it.<n><n>### Further Discussion:<n>It would make more sense to put the table on a piece of floor if you had a rug on it because you could put a rug on and on top of your rug you would have your table. This way you can make your rug more beautiful, which is something that is not really the main purpose of a table (at least for a house).<n><n>### Instructor's Insight:Instructions and tasks like this teach the students not only critical thinking and logical reasoning necessary for the success, but may even be applied on other areas of development of the students, such as leadership and team development.<n>

Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		Answer: Increase<n><n>### Why?:This answer is what I think the correct answer is based on the question the information the question asked for and the information I have found and used. I also thought this because of the words "heat up" which I thought meant to get hotter. However since the "hotter" meant more hot, I was mistaken and was wrong. My answer was also correct because I know the fact that if the sun is out, then it means it is warming up. If it's cooling down then it has to be because of the sun and that happens at night. So I was also able to add the fact that temperature change rapidly, to mean that the temperature is constantly changing, so its going up and down quickly. So I can also conclude that there's no way the temperature can drop to zero because if it is zero no sun or heat from the sun can be present which means no heat can be present.<n><n>### Input2:A 60-foot tree was planted in a park 2 years ago.  Over the last year there has been a 2.5% growth rate.  How many inches tall is the tree today?<n><n>### Response2:Answer:160<n><n>### Why:Since the question had me asked to estimate what I thought the answer was I thought since growth was 2.5%, (60 x 2.5) = 150. So I had to add the 150 to what the question originally asked which was a 60-foot-tree. I originally thought the answer would have been 63 because I originally thought that the 2.5% was a % increase and 60 x 1.025 = 63. Which does not equal the answer though.<n><n>### Task 3<n><n>### Instructions:A mathematician is trying to write a formula for an unknown x.  The formula must include the following three constants:<n><n>A: -1C: -10D: -3<n><n>He writes the formula x=A10C + D, but that does not produce the correct answer. If he writes the formula like this instead:<n><n>x3 -6x +6 = A -10 C -3.<n>What x did this equation give for the constant C?<n><n>### Demostration:

The best answer is option B as the question is where to look and not how many deodorants there were. Option C asks what to do with a deodorant so it's not a useful question.<n><n>---<n>© 2020 Trilogy Education Services, LLC, a 2U, Inc. brand. Confidential and Proprietary. All Rights Reserved.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:When we are thankful for getting something what do we do? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		 D<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>#### Solution 1<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>1) The following input contains an instruction.<n>2) Write a response that approprietly completes the request. <n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>Input: The pizza dough is a basic dough.  You need to spread 1 cup of sauce over the dough.  After you spread the sauce, you need to spread 1/2 cup of cheese over it.  After spreading the sauce and cheese, you need to place two toppings over the cheese. Last, you need to bake the pizza in the oven according to the following schedule: 5 minutes at 400 degrees Fahrenheit, 5 minutes at 350 degrees Fahrenheit.  How long does it take to bake the pizzas from start to finish?<n>Answer: 22 minutes and 10 seconds<n><n>### Solutions:<n><n>#### Solution2<n><n>### Instructon: Answer the instruction.<n><n>### Input Demonstration: The following input contains an instructon. Write a response that accurately completes the instruction.<n><n>Input: The distance from Los Angeles to Boston by car is 2,287 miles.  The distance from Boston by car is 783 miles. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Some might say that if you want to do something that results in changing society then you need to start from within, to do this what would you be doing? Choices:  A: riots B: vote C: change yourself D: social activism E: change clothes<n><n>### Response:		Change myself.<n><n>### Input : What does every good leader do? Choices : A: make fun of their followers B: find out how many followers they have C: look out for snakes D: get drunk most of the time E: have a lot of followers<n><n>### Response : Find out how many followers.<n><n>###Input:What will you do today? Choices: A: stay in today B: party, go to a ball C: buy new shoes D: get a new dress E: see your family<n><n>### Response：See my family<n><n>### Input  : Why can you not go to bed if you still have a lot of things to do? Choices :  A: you still have things to do B: go to bed, you can do it tomorrow C: you still have new toys to play with D: you will be busy in the morning playing E: you have to finish what you started<n><n>### Response  : You still have new things to play with.<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>- 1. Complete the table below by entering 0 or 1 to indicate whether the cell can or cannot be a solution.<n><n>|Solution    |Cells|<n>|-------------|-------|<n>| A          |  0   |<n>| B          |  0   *|<n>| C          |  0   0  |<n>| D          | 0 1   *|<n>| E          |  0  0  |<n>| F          |  0  1  |<n>- 2. Choose the letter that best matches the situation.<n><n>|A             |B             |C             |D             |E             |<n>|--------------|--------------|---------------|--------------|------------|<n>|A             |A             |A             *|B             |E             *|<n>|A             *|A             |A              *|B             x|C             *|<n>||||||<n>|E             |E             |E             *<n>|E             |A             *<n>- 3. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: heart attacks B: hole in your socks C: exhaustion D: shortness of breath E: blisters<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Democratization:<n>> _"[E]very action is of the same kind as its predecessor and is, therefore, a consequence of the preceding one."_<n><n>When dealing with an instruction like this, you'll often want to check if you answered the right thing. To do so, you may need a few pre-computed values. You may need to write the answer you want. But to do that, you'll need to know how many people it could be. I know of no way to calculate this exactly.<n><n>You could do the following  (very) unoptimized strategy:<n><n>- Get the first 4 elements for an input from the array you're parsing.<n>- Check if you gave the correct answer.<n>- If you did, output "No need to parse rest of the input."<n>- If you didn't, check for the type of the next element.<n>- If you are expecting a choice, increment the index you're evaluating until you find the next choice's type.<n>- If the next element is an integer, write the previous element.<n>- Repeat until you have parsed all the tokens.<n>- If it is the very last thing, write what the correct answer is.<n>- Parse the array of tokens.<n><n>If you'd like, you can make it more efficient (but also more complicated), by keeping track of which tokens are the correct choice.<n><n>### Demo:<n>```<n>Input:<n>A. What would form on your feet if you were jogging?<n>B. heart attacks<n>C. holes in socks<n>D. exhaustion<n>E. blisters<n><n>Output:<n>B<n><n>Input:<n>C. Why your brain hurts after using JavaScript while drunk<n>D. holes in socks.<n><n>Output:<n>C<n><n>Input:<n>Q. Why is JavaScript harder to master than other languages?<n>A. Because it's not as well written, for example in python you can't really accidentally mess up.<n>B. because you can't use it in a drunk state<n><n>Output:<n>A<n>```<n>

The mayor has invited 5 different business leaders  and 4 union representatives to the discussion.  Everyone who attends knows the issues the city council is facing.  How many total leaders in attendance do not actually know the city's issues?<n><n>### Response<n>2. A mayor can count to 5 + B, and B can count to 4, C can count to 3, D can count to 2, and E can count to 1. It is therefore 2 more not knowing.<n><n>### You might need to explain your answers:<n>Explain your process and why you answered as you did. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If children get confused walking home where may they go? Choices:  A: play chess B: sun themselves C: wrong house D: set table E: gettable<n><n>### Response:		The word play chess can not be used in this statement. This is because the chess is a game, which is not associated to walking home or wrong houses. So, the statement may be E.<n><n>### InputA family of 3 had 440 apples which they shared among 210 members of a community. How many apples each member received?<n><n>### Response A family of four having 304 apples shared among 108 members in other community have this relationship (304/108)=2.689. That's why the answer is 2.7.

If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The graveyard was important to build, where should it be built? Choices:  A: arlington B: church property C: out back D: every town E: cemetery<n><n>### Response:		The answer A<n><n>### The number of days since 1/1/2010<n><n>### A:273703<n><n>### B:273710<n><n>## How much was bought at the store?<n><n>## A:5795<n><n>## B:5795 <n><n>### ANSWER(C):<n><n>### The second and third paragraph are complete sentences.<n><n>### Except the third one.<n><n>### Because there should be a comma before the end of the third paragraph.<n><n>### So the third paragraph is a run on sentence.<n><n>### Run-on Sentences are sentences that cannot be divided without putting a period or comma at the end of the clause to separate it for further sentences.<n><n>## ANSWER(A):<n><n>### Because the sentence needs to end in a period instead of the word "and".<n><n>### So there is no clause.<n><n>### There is no sentence.<n><n>## A:Dad’s birthday is on November 22. Dad was born on November 20.<n><n>## B:Dad was born on November20<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### In the first line, the sentence needs to end with a period instead of " "<n><n>### The sentence ends with period. <n><n>### In one line, the words have a different case than the "Dad" at the beggining of the sentence.<n><n>## C:House, the cat<n><n>### The complete sentence that goes with the phrase "I saw a cat. It was... <n><n>### The subject was  "cat" and the predicate was "house" <n><n>### There was a comma error.<n><n>### If we remove them, the sentence will be complete.<n><n>### A sentence has three basic elements, the subject, predicate, and verb. They must all have same case. <n><n>## D:House, the dog, walks a mile.<n><n>### The question mark does not belong in the sentence.<n><n><n>

How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. This answer needs an explanation.<n><n>### Input - Demonstration:Answer the question using the information provided<n><n>Input: How much does the truck cost?<n>Input: What is the cost of repairing the truck?<n>Input: If the repair cost was 2,000, how much is the original value of the truck?<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Given two strings called s, and t, print whether s is a Rotation of t or not. If s is a rotation of t, print “Is a rotation” and the count of distinct characters in s.<n><n>### Output<n><n>Is a rotation<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Rotation is a process where characters of a given string are permuted. A rotation of a given string s takes input as a string t. A rotation of a string s is a string, which is formed by taking the character of the i-th position from the s string and shifting it to the (4i − 1) position.<n><n>The following table depicts the possible rotations of a string.<n><n>|Input String|Output String|<n>|-----|----|<n>|abcd|baac|<n>|abxy|adxy|<n>|abxyz|adxyz|<n><n>### Demostration - Note:This answer needs a diagram.<n><n>### Solution 1<n><n>Write an if block to check the string and print.<n><n>### Soltion 2 (Using Regex)<n><n>Write a RegExp for "aaa". Then use test function and iterate over the string using Array.from function.<n><n>```javascript<n>regex.test(string).then().map((character) => console.log(character))<n>```<n><n>### Solution Usage 1 (Using forEach)<n><n>Write an if statement, for a character to print either not identical or identical.<n><n>###Solution Usage 2 (+) (Using forEach)

Where might the restaurant be located? Choices:  a:  suburb b: farming community c: new york city d: a city e: town<n><n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>##### a<n><n>### Input/Data:<n>* In the past decade, the number of visitors to the Smithsonian Museum has risen almost a dozenfold<n>* 118,000 people visited the museum last week<n>* In July, 127,000 people had visited the museum in 2011<n><n>* Last month, 145,000 people attended a circus show<n>* The circus show was only 30,000 people larger than the largest audience for the show. <n><n>**If the circus show was a one time event, what was the average monthly attendance for the circus show?**<n><n><n>**Explanation/Solution**<n><n>The sum must be the same as the difference.<n><n>* Sum: 118,334<n>* Difference: 127,962 - 118,255 = 19,707.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>* If 10,000,000 apples were produced and distributed to schools, how many apples were distributed to each school? Assume 50 students per school.<n>* How many oranges were produced?<n><n>**Answer:** The school received 50 apples for each of 5 schools, or 250 apples total. For the number of oranges: 10,020,000 oranges / 10,045,001<n>**Explanation:** I chose a "simpler" school situation, where each school received the same amount of apples. What if 3 schools received 250 appes per and 2 received 100 apples?<n><n>### Question<n><n>The number of homes on the North Pole is 21800 and the number of homes on

Choices: A: 70years B: 4 years C: 5 years D: 10 years<n><n>### Response Answer: C<n><n>### Instructions: Enter an expression into the input box, and press the Run expression button, which shows the result. Your expression must not contain any mathematical operations like +, -, *, or / and any other operations that will cause division or multiplication should also be replaced according to the instructions.<n><n>### Example expression: 40+7-3*4<n><n>### Instraction: The above expression needs to be replaced. The value of expression will be shown without division or multiplication operators and the result will be 10 more than the previous calculation. The first operation in the expression should be replaced with the first operation in the input and so on. For each operation you make, the result of that operation is added to the result of the previous calculation, and finally the second operation is replaced with the fourth operation and the third operation is replaced with the fifth operation.<n><n>### Answer: 472<n><n>Input: 50+30-2+30*9-24<n><n>### Example:<n><n>### A.<n><n>### D.<n><n>### How much money did the baker earn in the whole day?<n><n>### A) 20 dollars.<n><n>### B) 23 dollars.<n><n>## Conclusion:<n><n>Congratulations - you have completed the LeetCode-Test. If you like it, please  :heart: below and star this repository. Thanks!<n>

Your program can get the number of students participating and the number of students who obtained 15 or more and print that to the user.<n><n>### Output:<n>Class average: 15<n>Number of students who got 15 or above: 34<n>Number of students who get less than 16: 25<n>

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week. Choices:  A: run programs B: play games C: control model D: power down E: reason exists<n><n>### Response:		<n>**[E]** A computer can only do as much as it is told to do, and that is by us. So the reason all computers exist is because a person told them what they were supposed to do.<n><n>### Input<n>Sherri is using 2.97 miles of rope to draw a circle, when exactly 2.97 feet of rope are required to draw a circle, what fraction of the rope is Sherri using?<n><n>### Response<n>**[B]** A quarter of the rope Sherri is using (0.25)<n><n>

Choices:  A: bright B: pointed C: correct D: acute angled E: clear<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>B<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Use an equation to answer the problem.<n><n>### Input <n>Input:If twice a year John takes up two additional weights for his workout.  If he picks up 30, 15, then 25, what will be the total of the weights he is now lifting?<n>Answer: 90<n><n>### Response <n>Response:<n><n>```<n>$ (15 + 25)  + 30  =  60$<n>```<n>### Instruiction:<n><n>Answer the following question that has a graph showing how temperature and salinity of water in the Indian Ocean decreased over 3 weeks.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>We should first find out the line that the water salinity is going up at an increasing rate at first but when we get to 58 units the line goes down. We can use a straight line to represent this information, We already know that the lines are paralell and the 1st line goes down in the same rate as the 2nd line goes up. the equation for the second line is 0.1t - 0.63. <n>The equation now is 1t - 0 and we can solve for t and plug the values in<n><n>$t = \frac{-0.63 + 0.1t}{-0.1} $<n><n>$ t=-0.73 + 0.45t $<n><n>Now we can plug those values into the second line that was given to us and we get<n><n>$ y-2 = 19.5 + 0.73x $<n><n>$ y = 19.73 + 1.29x $<n><n>And now we also get the slope and yintercept by solving for $m=\frac{ \Delta y}{ \Delta x} $<n><n>$  \Delta y = 49 - -17.73, \Delta x = 10$<n><n>$m =\frac{49 - -16.73}{10} $<n><n>$m = 0.233 $<n><n>$$ y = 19+1.29(1+0.233 x) $$ <n><n>This was the data I used<n><n>

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>Input: A club is going to get additional members so that they will have 5 more than twice their current number of their members. If the club has 10 members now, how many additional members do they need?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Why might a person take a vacation? Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		<n>* A,B,E<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question.<n><n>## Below is an instruction that asks a question with many possible answers. Write a response that provides an appropriate answer choice.<n><n>How do we know we live in the golden era of television? There are several arguments that we live in an era of amazing television. Here are some of them.<n><n>### ****Answer choice C***<n><n>* TV is more socially acceptable in today’s society than ever before. As a result of that, TV and filmmakers are creating more shows about social topics.<n><n>### Multiple Choice<n>#### Select the following. Each option can only be selected once.<n><n><n><n>## Below is a prompt that includes a quote with no explanation. Choose an option that best describes what the quote means.<n><n>“We’ve never been so close to space as in the 20th century, and that’s incredible.”<n>#### Choose the letter of the answer that best describes the quote.<n><n>#### Answer Letter<n> - A: "This quote states that the world has never been close to space as in this century."<n><n><n><n>##**Below is just a bit of text. What does the following quote mean?*<n><n>"I never knew what poverty was."<n><n>#### Choose the appropriate letter based on which of the choices best describes what the quote is saying.<n><n><n>#### Answer Letters:<n> - A: He experienced it, just didn’t know it.<n> - B: She’s wealthy because she never experienced hardships.<n><n><n><n><n><n># Code of Conduct<n>## You have signed up as a Cool Kids Programmer and you agree to adhere strictly to our Code of Conduct.<n>## If you are interested in being notified when the contest opens, complete the form below.<n><n># Interested in helping?<n>Sign me up to help!<n>
